newsitem.title: USA: Dow rallies to record high, Nasdaq surges again.
newsitem.headline: Dow rallies to record high, Nasdaq surges again.

text.p: Wall Street stocks finished broadly higher on Tuesday, lifting the Dow industrials to an all-time high and propelling Nasdaq to its ninth consecutive record close.
The Dow climbed 53 points to close unofficially at 7976, the blue chip average's first new high in a week.
Tech stocks extended their dominance, with Hewlett-Packard Co ranking as the Dow's strongest component for a third straight day, climbing 3-1/2 to 68-9/16 in New York Stock Exchange activity.

Hewlett-Packard's gains again mirrored those among the resurgent tech group, where mounting optimism has powered Nasdaq to a string of record highs second only to a 10-session run that ended May 1, 1996.
In the process, investors have largely shaken off the effects of some high-profile earnings warnings early in the quarter, most notably from Intel Corp.
"There is a growing conviction the group is going to do better earnings-wise later in the year and into 1998," said Al Goldman, analyst at A.G. Edwards and Sons.
Shortly after the close, Intel reported second quarter earnings of $0.92 per share, two cents higher than First Call's consensus analyst estimate.
The powerhouse performance in the tech sector appeared to breathe new life into suddenly sluggish blue chips, which have tracked sideways since nearing the 8,000 mark early last week.
The Dow also overcame some concerns that the soaring U.S. dollar, which has approached six-year highs against the German mark, might eventually erode profits at multinational corporations.

While analysts acknowledged currency exchange rates could become a burden at some point, many argued the strong dollar also brought near-term benefits offsetting longer-term profit concerns for stocks.

"The dollar's rise is a two-way sword," said Pierre Ellis, senior economist at Primark Decision Economics. "It hurts the profit outlook of big multinationals but valuations of our markets are helped because foreign buyers come in."
With quarterly earnings season in high gear, however, the market's mood is likely to shift with the tide of major earnings reports.
An early boost came today from Texas Instruments Inc, which leaped 12 points to 109-1/2 after the semiconductor giant reported earnings that more than tripled from year-ago levels.

The solid results at first boosted chip stocks, then the broader technology group, and then, for the first time in a week, tech stocks helped lift the broader market, putting the Dow back in position to crack 8,000.
"While the techs had been strong, they were playing catch-up and now everything is finally even," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd.
"The market finally starts looking like it's ready to start firing on all cylinders," he said.
In individual issues, Merrill Lynch and Co Inc gained 2-3/8 to 66-1/16 after reporting a second quarter profit of $481 million, the highest in its history.
CCA Prison Realty Trust PZN.N gained 7-7/8 to 28-7/8 in its Wall Street debut. The company is a real estate investment trust focusing on private prison properties.
Lam Research Corp jumped 8-3/8 to 58 after Cowen & Co upgraded the semiconductor equipment maker to buy from neutral.
The S&P 500 index rose 7.38 points to 925.76, a record.
The Nasdaq Composite rose 18.23 points to 1542.11.
((-- Wall Street desk, 212-859-1730))
